subsection.title: Solving a Radical Equation
subsection.p: A radical equation is one in which the variable appears under a square root or other radical. We solve simple radical equations by raising both sides to the appropriate power. For example, to solve the equation \sqrt{x+3}=4 we square both sides to find (\sqrt{x+3})^2 \amp = 4^2 x+3 \amp = 16 You can check that x=13 is the solution for this equation.

solution.p: We first divide both sides of the equation by 4 to isolate the radical. \sqrt[3]{x-9} = 3 Next, we cube both sides of the equation. (\sqrt[3]{x-9})^3 \amp = 3^3 x-9 \amp = 27 x \amp = 36 The solution is 36. We can also solve the equation graphically by graphing y=4\sqrt[3]{x-9}, as shown in the figure. The point (36,12) lies on the graph, so x=36 is the solution of the equation ~4\sqrt[3]{x-9} = 12.

subsection.title: Extraneous Solutions
subsection.p: Whenever we raise both sides of an equation to an even power, it is possible to introduce false or extraneous solutions. For example, the equation \sqrt{x}=-5 has no solution, because \sqrt{x} is never a negative number. However, if we try to solve the equation by squaring both sides, we find (\sqrt{x})^{\alert{2}}\amp = (-5)^{\alert{2}} x\amp = 25 You can check that 25 is not a solution to the original equation, \sqrt{x}=-5 , because \sqrt{25} does not equal -5.
Raising both sides of an equation to an odd power does not introduce extraneous solutions. However, if we raise both sides to an even power, we should check each solution in the original equation.

Thus, in , the original equation is not equivalent to (\sqrt{x+2})^2+4^2=x^2 This is because (a + b)^2 \ne a^2 + b^2. subsection.title: Solving Formulas
subsection.p: We can also solve formulas involving radicals for one variable in terms of the others.

subsection.title: Equations with More than One Radical
subsection.p: Sometimes we need to square both sides of an equation more than once in order to eliminate all the radicals.

warning.p: Recall that we cannot solve a radical equation by squaring each term separately. So it is incorrect to begin by writing (\sqrt{x-7})^2+(\sqrt{x})^2=7^2 We must square the entire expression on each side of the equal sign as one piece.

subsection.title: Simplifying \sqrt[n]{a^n}
subsection.p: We have seen that raising to a power is the inverse operation for extracting roots, so that (\sqrt[n]{a})^n = a For example, (\sqrt[4]{16})^4 = 16~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~(\sqrt[5]{x})^5 = x What if the power and root operations occur in the opposite order? Is it always true that ~\sqrt[n]{a^n} = a~?

First, consider the case where the index is an odd number. For example, \sqrt[3]{2^3} = \sqrt[3]{8} = 2 ~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~\sqrt[3]{(-2)^3} = \sqrt[3]{-8} = -2
Because every real number has exactly one nth root if n is odd, we see that, \sqrt[n]{a^n} = a,~~~~\text{for}~n~\text{odd} However, if n is even, then a^n is positive, regardless of whether a itself is positive or negative, and hence \sqrt[n]{a^n} is positive also. For example, if a=-3, then \sqrt{(-3)^2} = \sqrt{9} = 3 In this case, \sqrt{a^2} does not equal a, because a is negative but \sqrt{a^2} is positive. We must be careful when taking even roots of powers. We have the following special relationship for even roots. \sqrt[n]{a^n} = \abs{a},~~~~~\text{for}~n~\text{even}
We summarize our results in the box below.
In particular, note that it is not always true that \sqrt{a^2} = a, unless we know that a \ge 0. Otherwise, we can only assume that \sqrt{a^2} = \abs{a}.
